children.name: try
children.definition: to take action in order to do something that you may not be able to do: cố gắng
examples: Sorry I didn’t phone you. I did try, but your line was busy.
I tried all the keys, but none of them would open the door.
Let’s have a rest and then we’ll try again.

children.name: hard
examples: She was trying hard not to show her impatience.

children.name: desperately
examples: They try desperately to please other people.

children.name: unsuccessfully/in vain
examples: He has tried unsuccessfully to quit smoking.

children.name: try your best/hardest
children.definition: make as much effort as possible
examples: Try your best to block out other distractions.

children.name: have a try
examples: B2/ have a goespecially UK B2 []spokento try to do sth, especially when you think youmaynotsucceed:

children.name: try to do something
examples: He tried to control his voice.
She was trying not to cry.

children.name: try and do something
examples: Try and take some form of daily exercise.

children.name: try hard/desperately (to do something)(= make a lot of effort to do something )
examples: She dabbed at her face and tried hard not to sniff.
Itried everythingto lose weight with no success.

children.name: try your best/hardest (to do something)(= make as much effort as possible to do something )
examples: I tried my best to comfort her.
Itried and tried(= kept making an effort )and eventually I was offered a job.
Try ashemight(= as hard as he could ), he could not get the incident out of his mind.

children.name: it wasn’t for lack/want of trying(= used to say that if someone does not achieve something it is not because they have not tried )
examples: They didn’t get any goals, but it wasn’t for the lack of trying.

children.name: you couldn’t do something if you tried(= used to say that someone does not have the skill or ability to do something )
examples: She couldn’t speak French if she tried.
I can’t get the lid off this jar. Do you want to have a try?
Have a go - you might be able to get the answer.

children.name: have a try/go at doing something
examples: We had a go at trying to coax the cat indoors using scraps of food.

children.name: attempt
children.definition: to try to do sthdifficult, dangerous, or new.Attemptis more formal thantryand is used especially in written English:
examples: No one has attempted this experiment before.
A rescue was attempted by Coast Guards, but it was not successful.

children.name: make an attempt[]
examples: B2 to try on one occasion to do sth, especially sth difficult, dangerous, or new:

children.name: attempt to do sth
examples: He was attempting to climb one of the world’s highest mountains.
Any prisoner who attempts to escape will be shot.
Someone had attempted to open the car door.
They are attempting to become the first to climb Everest without oxygen tanks.

children.name: make an attempt to do sth
examples: I made an attempt to apologize, but Brian wouldn’t even talk to me.
Several attempts were made to negotiate with the gunmen.

children.name: make no attempt to do something
examples: The protesters made no attempt to resist arrest.

children.name: see if you can do sth
children.definition: to try to do sth - use this either to offer to do sth for sb, or to ask sb to do sth for you:
examples: If you want to come to the show, I’ll see if I can get you a ticket.
See if you can get him to change his mind.

children.name: endeavour
children.definition: UK /endeavorUS  formal to try to do sth: cố gắng, ráng

children.name: endeavour to do sth
examples: We always endeavour to provide our customers with the highest standards of service.
I remained for some time endeavouring to engage Mr Campbell in conversation.
We always endeavor to please our customers.

children.name: seek
children.definition: to do sthformalto try toachievesomething, especially sth that may take alongtimebut which you think isimportant: cố gắng, theo đuổi
examples: The Smiths are now seeking to take their case to the European Court.
For over two decades the USA sought to prevent the spread of communism in Southeast Asia.
Our economic policies seek to increase productivity, expand markets and create jobs.

children.name: struggle
children.definition: to do sthto try very hard to do sth that is very difficult, especially for a long: gắng sức, nỗ lực
examples: There are too many families struggling to survive on low incomes.
I found my father struggling to lift one end of an enormous chest of drawers.
She struggled to express her feelings.
She’s still struggling to give up smoking.
Many of these families are struggling to survive.

children.name: to try very hard to do sth
try hard
children.definition: to make a lot of effort, because you want very much to do sth: cố hết sức
examples: No matter how hard I tried, I couldn’t get the window to open.

children.name: try hard to do sth
examples: I was trying hard not to laugh.
You must try harder to get your homework done on time.

children.name: make an effort
children.definition: to try hard to do sth, especially sth you donot wantto do but you think youshould do: nỗ lực
examples: ▪ Can’t you make more of an effort?

children.name: make an effort to do something
examples: ▪ I made an effort to sound interested in what he was saying.
▪ I wish you’d make an effort to get on with my friends.

children.name: make no effort to do something
examples: ▪ She makes absolutely no effort to see the other person’s point of view.

children.name: strive
children.definition: to try hard toachievesth, especially when this is difficult: cố gắng, phấn đấu, đấu tranh

children.name: strive to do sth
examples: Toni has been striving to achieve musical recognition for the past ten years.

children.name: strive for
examples: The company must constantly strive for greater efficiency.

children.name: be at pains to do sth
children.definition: to make a lot of effort to do sth, especially toexplainsth people donotunderstandcorrectly: cố hết sức để giải thích
examples: Mrs Henessy was at pains to say that she was fighting for a principle, not just for financial compensation.

children.name: go to great lengths
children.definition: to do sth to be willing to useanymethodthat is necessary in order toachievesomething, even if this involves beingdishonest, breaking the law etc: cố làm gì bằng mọi cách
examples: Health professionals have gone to great lengths to reassure patients that the treatment is safe.
Some firms will go to great lengths, including spying, to obtain information about their competitors.

children.name: when you try to do sth
attempt
children.definition: when you try to do something, especially something you havenot tried before:
examples: attempt to do something
All attempts to control inflation have failed.
attempt at (doing) something
her feeble attempts at humour
at the first/second etc attempt
She passed her driving test at the first attempt.
in an attempt to do sth
The government has announced that it will fund an extra 10,000 doctors in an attempt to reduce waiting times for operations.
an unsuccessful/a successful attemptan unsuccessful attempt to overthrow the government

children.name: make an attempt
examples: She made several attempts to escape.

children.name: abandon/give up an attempt
examples: They had to abandon their attempt to climb the mountain.

children.name: fail/succeed in your attempt
examples: He failed in his attempt to set a new Olympic record.

children.name: foil/thwart an attemptformal
children.definition: make it fail
examples: Troops loyal to the general foiled the assassination attempt.

children.name: an attempt fails/succeeds
examples: All attempts to find a cure have failed.

children.name: on the first/second etc attempt
children.definition: alsoat the first/second etc attemptBritish English
examples: The car started at the second attempt.

children.name: a vain attempt
children.definition: one that does not succeed
examples: They worked through the night in a vain attempt to finish on schedule.

children.name: a desperate attempt
children.definition: that involves a lot of effort
examples: Doctors made a desperate attempt to save his life.

children.name: a deliberate/conscious attempt
examples: His question was a deliberate attempt to humiliate her.

children.name: a serious/genuine attempt
examples: This is the first serious attempt to tackle the problem.

children.name: an abortive attemptformal
children.definition: unsuccessful
examples: They made an abortive attempt to keep the company going.

children.name: a futile attempt
children.definition: certain to fail and not worth doing
examples: I jumped up and down in a futile attempt to keep warm.

children.name: a doomed attempt
children.definition: certain to fail, and causing something very bad to happen
examples: His attempt to reach the Pole was doomed from the beginning.

children.name: a brave/bold/gallant/valiant attemptapproving
children.definition: one that you admire, but that is unsuccessful
examples: The previous government made a brave attempt to tackle the problem.|She made a valiant attempt to continue playing, but the pain was too much.

children.name: a blatant attemptdisapproving
children.definition: when someone openly tries to do something bad
examples: It was a blatant attempt to hide the truth.

children.name: a final/last attempt
examples: They made one final attempt to make their marriage work.

children.name: a last-ditch attempt
children.definition: a final attempt to achieve something before it is too late
examples: Negotiators are making a last-ditch attempt to save the agreement.

children.name: a rescue attempt
examples: Two firefighters were hurt in the rescue attempt.

children.name: an assassination attempt
children.definition: an attempt to kill a leader
examples: De Gaulle survived an assassination attempt in 1961.

children.name: a suicide attempt
children.definition: an attempt to kill yourself
examples: He was admitted to hospital after a suicide attempt.

children.name: a coup attempt
children.definition: an attempt to change the government, usually by force
examples: The US helped to crush the coup attempt.

children.name: effort
children.definition: an attempt to do something, especially when this involves a lot of hard work or determination: nỗ lực
examples: Please make an effort to be polite.

children.name: make an effort
children.definition: try
examples: She made an effort to change the subject of the conversation.

children.name: put effort into
children.definition: doing
examples: something(= try hard to do something )Let’s try again, only put more effort into it this time.

children.name: take the effort out of something
children.definition: make it easy
examples: An automatic car takes the effort out of driving.

children.name: something takes effort
children.definition: alsoit takes effort to do something
examples: (= you have to try hard )It takes a sustained effort to quit smoking.

children.name: something requires/involves effortformal
children.definition: it takes effort
examples: Trying to get my mother to change her mind requires considerable effort.

children.name: successful
examples: Their efforts were successful, and they won the contract.

children.name: unsuccessful
examples: Efforts to save the hospital from closure have been unsuccessful.

children.name: futile
children.definition: having no chance of succeeding, and therefore not worth doing
examples: Doctors knew that any effort to save his life would be futile.

children.name: a big/great effort
examples: The government has made a big effort to tackle the problem of poverty.

children.name: considerable effort
children.definition: a lot of effort
examples: The police put considerable effort into finding his car.

children.name: a supreme/tremendous effort
children.definition: a very big effort
examples: It was only with a supreme effort that Roger controlled his temper.

children.name: a special effort
children.definition: one that you do not normally make
examples: I made a special effort to be nice to the children.

children.name: a constant effort
children.definition: one that never stops
examples: Walking was a constant effort.

children.name: a sustained effort
children.definition: one that you continue making for a long time
examples: It will take a sustained effort over the next 5 years to achieve our objectives.

children.name: a conscious/deliberate effort
children.definition: one that you concentrate on in order to achieve something
examples: He made a conscious effort to become a better person.

children.name: a determined effort
children.definition: showing a lot of determination
examples: She had made a determined effort to lose weight.

children.name: a desperate effort
children.definition: one you make when you are in a very bad situation
examples: The fox made a desperate effort to get away.

children.name: a concerted effort
children.definition: involving a lot of different actions, or a lot of people working together
examples: It will take a concerted effort to change the culture of binge-drinking in the country.

children.name: a joint/team effort
children.definition: involving a group or team of people
examples: We had many fine individual performances, but the win was a real team effort.

children.name: a collaborative/cooperative effortformal
children.definition: with different people or groups working together
examples: This was a collaborative effort involving the three largest energy companies.

children.name: physical/mental effort
examples: He struggled back from two sets down to win the match, showing great physical and mental effort.

children.name: a final/last-ditch effort
children.definition: a last effort, when you want very much to achieve something
examples: Sam took a deep breath and prepared herself for one final effort.

children.name: make the effort
children.definition: do something that requires some effort
examples: I felt too tired to go to a party, but decided to make the effort.

children.name: make every effort to do something
children.definition: try very hard
examples: I made every effort to see their point of view.

children.name: make no effort to do something
children.definition: not try at all
examples: They make no effort to speak the local language.

children.name: be
children.definition: well
examples: worth the effort(= used to say that something is worth doing even though it is hard )It’s a difficult place to get to, but it's well worth the effort.

children.name: an effort of will
children.definition: a big effort to do something that you find difficult because of the way you feel
examples: It took a huge effort of will not to cry.

children.name: with effortformal
children.definition: trying very hard
examples: With great effort, he managed to keep quiet.

children.name: without effort
children.definition: easily, without trying hard
examples: Her horse jumped the fence without any effort.

children.name: sb’s effort(s) to do sth
examples: Tom’s efforts to stop smoking haven’t been very successful.

children.name: effort at
examples: Further efforts at negotiation have broken down.

children.name: through sb’s efforts(= because of their efforts )
examples: The money was raised largely through the efforts of parents.

children.name: despite sb’s efforts
examples: Despite all our efforts we lost the game 1–0.

children.name: in an effort to do something
examples: The company has announced 500 job losses in an effort to cut costs.
Church leaders are prepared to meet the terroristsin an effort tofind peace.

children.name: drive
children.definition: a planned effort, especially by acompanyor agovernment, toachievea particular kind ofimprovementwithin ashorttime: sự nỗ lực

children.name: drive for
examples: ▪ We need a new drive for investment in Britain’s inner cities.

children.name: drive to do something
examples: ▪ The government must continue this drive to find new, cleaner forms of energy.

children.name: efficiency/economy/modernization etc drive
examples: ▪ As part of the bank’s efficiency drive substantial cuts are being made in the workforce.

children.name: try
children.definition: an attempt to do sth:
examples: She didn’t manage to break the record, but it was a good try.
‘You really think you can do that?’ ‘I’m going tohave a try.’
‘What are the chances for getting tickets now?’ ‘I guess I couldgive it a try.’
It might sound a ludicrous excuse but he thought it wasworth a try.
on the first/second etc try
Only half the students passed the test on their first try.
a good try‘Do you really think you can win?’ ‘I’m going to have a darn good try.’

children.name: have a try
examples: I decided to have one last try.

children.name: give it a tryinformal
examples: If your instinct is telling you to give it a try, then go ahead.

children.name: be worth a try
children.definition: be worth trying to do because you may succeed
examples: It’s worth a try – we’ve nothing to lose.

children.name: a nice try
children.definition: a good try that is not successful
examples: Nice try, Claudia, but not good enough, I’m afraid.

children.name: sb’s first/second try
examples: This is his first try at directing.

children.name: go
children.definition: an attempt to do sth:

children.name: ‘I can’t open this drawer.’ ‘Here, let mehave a go.’
examples: On the tour, everyone canhave a go atmaking a pot.
I’d thought about it for some time and decided togive it a go(= try to do something ).
Ihad a good go(= tried hard )at cleaning the silver.

children.name: at/in one go
examples: Ruby blew out all her candles at one go.
I’m not sure it will work butit’s worth a go.

children.name: endeavour
children.definition: UKendeavorUSformalan attempt to do sth new or difficult
examples: scientific/creative etc endeavour
an outstanding example ofhuman endeavor
endeavour to do something
Theymade every endeavourto find the two boys.
Despite ourbest endeavours, we couldn’t start the car.

children.name: to try as hard as you can
try your best
children.definition: do/  to try as hard as you can, even when the situation isdifficultand you arenot sureif you will succeed:

children.name: cố hết sức
examples: ▪ I don’t know if I’ll manage to get everything finished by Friday, but I’ll certainly do my best.

children.name: do/try your best to do sth
examples: ▪ Harry did his best to sound calm, but it was obvious that he was really annoyed.
▪ She tried her best not to laugh.

children.name: try as hard as you can
cố hết sức có thể
examples: ▪ Come on, try as hard as you can!
▪ I tried as hard as I could, but I still couldn’t get everything into one suitcase.

children.name: try as hard as you can to do something
examples: ▪ She tried as hard as she could to look interested.

children.name: give sth your best shot
children.definition: give something your best shot informalto try to do something as well as you can, even though you donot haveall thenecessaryskillsorequipment:

children.name: nỗ lực hết mình ( mặc dù ko có đủ kĩ năng, dụng cụ )
examples: ▪ I’m not promising I’ll succeed, but I’ll give it my best shot.

children.name: do your utmost
children.definition: do/try your utmost to try as much as you possibly can, and for as long as possible, toachievesth verydifficult: nỗ lực hết mình
examples: We have done our utmost. There is no more we could possibly do.

children.name: do your utmost to do something
examples: The Secretary of State assured reporters that the Administration was doing its utmost to avoid war.

children.name: do all you can U
children.definition: do everything/all you can to use everypossiblemethodto try to do something: làm mọi thứ ( để làm dc gì )
examples: ▪ I’m trying to help -- I’m doing everything I possibly can.
▪ I did everything I could to raise money, including selling my house.
▪ Her mother did all she could to encourage Tracy to study medicine.

children.name: give your all
children.definition: old fashion to use all yourenergyanddeterminationto achieve sth that is personally very important to you: dồn hết mọi sức lực
examples: She gave her all in the last race, but it wasn’t quite good enough to win.

children.name: as best you can
children.definition: if you do sth as best you can, especially something difficult or unpleasant, you try as hard as you can to do it because you cannot change the situation: tốt nhất có thể
examples: I cleaned the car up as best I could, but it still looked a mess.
We’ll have to manage as best we can without you.

children.name: to the best of your ability
children.definition: if you do sth to the best of your ability, you do it as well as you can, even if you are not sure that you are doing it very well: với hết khả năng
examples: ▪ I have always done my work to the best of my ability.
▪ All the children competed and performed to the best of their ability.

children.name: pull out all the stops
children.definition: to do everything possible to make anevent,celebration,competitionetc successful: nỗ lực hết mình ( cho một sự kiện )
examples: They gave me a great leaving party - they really pulled out all the stops.
If we pull out all the stops we should still be able to meet our deadline.

children.name: to try to get a job, position, prize etc
go for
children.definition: to try to get something you want very much, especially something that is difficult to achieve, such as a prize or a high position:
examples: ▪ Why don’t you go for a music scholarship?
▪ Are you going to go for the senior manager’s job?

children.name: try for
children.definition: to try to get something you want very much, for example a job, a prize, or a chance to study somewhere:
examples: ▪ Why don’t you try for this job as an Assistant Scientific Officer?
▪ I’ve decided to try for Harvard University.

children.name: angle for
children.definition: to try to make sb give you sth or say sth good about you without asking them directly:
examples: ▪ He was talking to Helen, angling for an invitation to her next party.
▪ She asked us how she looked, obviously angling for a compliment.

children.name: make a bid for
children.definition: to try to get an importantjobor apositionof power - used mainly innewspapers:

children.name: cố gắng dành ( một công việc, vị trị quan trọng )
examples: ▪ The party now feels the time is right to make a bid for power.

children.name: make a successful/unsuccessful bid for something
examples: ▪ Mr Meaney made an unsuccessful bid for the presidency two years ago.

children.name: shoot for
children.definition: Americaninformalto try to get an importantjoborachievesomething verydifficult:
examples: cố gáng dành ( 1 công việc quan trọng )
cố gắng đạt được ( 1 thành tích khó )
▪ There are five Democrat candidates shooting for president this year.
▪ Management is shooting for a 40% increase in productivity over six months.
▪ I think you should go for it - shoot for the top!

children.name: struggle for
children.definition: to make a lot of effort over alongperiodto get something that is veryimportantto you, but that is verydifficultto get:
examples: đấu tranh cho
▪ The people are still struggling for liberation from a brutal, oppressive regime.
▪ Many small businesses are struggling for survival in this difficult economic climate.
▪ He struggled for the right words to say.
struggle[countable noun]
struggle for for
▪ They are making some progress in their struggle for equal rights.

children.name: go all out
children.definition: to put all yourenergyanddeterminationinto trying to get or win something:
examples: dồn hết nỗ lực
go all out for
▪ The German team will be going all out for a win in next Saturday’s game.
go all out to do something
▪ We’re going all out to make our sales target this year.

children.name: to try very hard to help sb
bend over backwards
children.definition: bend/ lean over backwards to do sth to make every possible effort to behelpfulor topleasesb, even when thiscauses you difficulty or inconvenience: tìm mọi cách, tạo mọi điều kiện
examples: I bend over backwards to help him, but I never get any thanks for it.
The school have bent over backwards to accommodate Jan’s mobility difficulties.

children.name: go out of your way
children.definition: to do sth to make aspecialeffortto help sb, especially sb who needs help and support: cất công
examples: When Annie arrived, Harriman went out of his way to make life pleasant for her.
Jennifer knew what a difficult time I was having, and went out of her way to be friendly.

children.name: take the trouble
children.definition: to do sth to make aspecialeffortto do sth you think will be useful or helpful: chịu khó
examples: Take the trouble to learn all of your students’ names. They will appreciate it.
My bank manager took the trouble to write a very detailed letter answering my inquiry.

children.name: The head of department has been very helpful - he even took the trouble to show me round the premises during his lunch hour
to try even though you might not succeed
have a go
children.definition: ▪ I’m not sure I’ll be able to persuade him, but I’ll certainly .

children.name: have a go at
examples: ▪ I’ll have a go at repairing the roof myself.

children.name: give it a go B
children.definition: give it a go/a try/a whirl spoken informal to try to do something you have not tried before and do not know if you will be successful at:
examples: ▪ I’ve never done any acting before, but I’ll give it a try.
▪ It sounds like a great idea - let’s give it a whirl.
▪ You ought to give it a go at least.

children.name: battle
children.definition: noun(EFFORT)
examples: a determined effort to achieve something in a difficult situation or to change a bad situation:

children.name: heroic
children.definition: adjective

children.name: 2.informalIf you make a heroic attempt or effort to do something, you try very hard to do it
examples: Despite Roz's heroic efforts to liven it up, the party was a disaster.

children.name: pursue
children.definition: verbTRY TO DO
examples: 5. If you pursue a plan, activity or situation, you try to do it or achieve it, usually over a long period of time
He decided to pursue a career in television.
We need to decide soon what marketing strategy we should pursue for these new products.
Michael Evans is leaving the company to pursue his own business interests.
She is ruthless in pursuing her goals.
pursuitnounATTEMPTC2
3. [ U ] when you try to achieve a plan, activity or situation, usually over a long period of time
the pursuitofhappiness
The company is ruthlessinits pursuitofprofit.
The union is on strikeinpursuitof(= the act of trying to achieve) a 10% pay increase.

children.name: battle
children.definition: verb

children.name: 2. to try hard to achieve something in a difficult situation
examples: He had to battleagainstprejudice to get a job.
The parents battledforthe right to be involved in the decision-making.
We battledwiththe elementstoget the roof fixed.

children.name: bid
children.definition: nounATTEMPT

children.name: 3. an attempt to achieve or get something
examples: Her bidforre-election was unsuccessful.
The company has managed to fight off a hostiletakeoverbid (= an attempt by another company to take control of it) .
The government has reduced the cost of borrowing in a bidtoget the economy moving again.

children.name: quest
examples: [ + to infinitive ]She does aerobics four times a week in her questtoachieve the perfect body.

children.name: a long search for something that is difficult to find, or an attempt to achieve something difficult
examples: Nothing will stop themintheir questfortruth.
She went to Indiaona spiritual quest.

children.name: summon
children.definition: verbPRODUCE STRENGTH

children.name: 2. to increase your bravery or strength, especially with an effort
examples: It took me six months to summon(up)thecourageto ask him out for a drink.

children.name: make a go of
children.definition: sth(US usuallytry)

children.name: to try to make something succeed, usually by working hard
examples: She's really making a go of her new antique shop.
I can't see him ever making a go of accountancy.

children.name: get your act together
children.definition: getyouract togetherinformal

children.name: to start to organize yourself so that you do things in an effective way
examples: She's so disorganized - I wish she'd get her act together.
